definitions.definition: away from the inside of a place or thing

examples.text: She ran out into the corridor.
She shook the bag and some coins fell out.
I got out of bed.
He opened the box and **out jumped** a frog.
**Out you go!** *(= used to order somebody to leave a room)*
He ran out the door.

definitions.definition: away from or not at home or their place of work

examples.text: I called Liz but she was out.
Let's go out this evening *(= for example to a restaurant or club)*.
We haven't had a **night out** for weeks.
Mr Green is out of town this week.
I got an **out of office** reply to my email.

definitions.definition: outside; not in a building

examples.text: It's cold out.
There were children playing out in the street.

definitions.definition: used to show that something/somebody is removed from a place, job, etc.

examples.text: This detergent is good for getting stains out.
We want this government out.
He got thrown out of the restaurant.

definitions.definition: away from the edge of a place

examples.text: The boy dashed out into the road.
Don't lean out of the window.

definitions.definition: used to show where something comes from

examples.text: He drank his beer out of the bottle.
a romance straight out of a fairy tale
I paid for the damage out of my savings.
We'll get the truth out of her.

definitions.definition: used to show what something is made from

examples.text: a statue made out of bronze

definitions.definition: used to show that somebody/something does not have any of something

examples.text: We're out of milk.
He's been **out of work** for six months.
You're **out of luck**—she left ten minutes ago.

definitions.definition: used to show that somebody/something is not or no longer in a particular state or condition

examples.text: Try and stay out of trouble.
I watched the car until it was **out of sight**.

definitions.definition: used to show that somebody is no longer involved in something

examples.text: It was an awful job and I'm glad to be out of it.
He gets out of the army in a few weeks.
They'll be out *(= of prison)* on bail in no time.
Brown goes on to the semi-finals but Lee is out.

definitions.definition: from a particular number or set

examples.text: You scored six out of ten.
Two out of three people think the President should resign.

definitions.definition: clearly and loudly so that people can hear

examples.text: to **call/cry/shout out**
Read it **out loud**.
Nobody **spoke out** in his defence.

definitions.definition: a long or a particular distance away from a place or from land

examples.text: She's working out in Australia.
He lives right out in the country.
The boats are all out at sea.
The ship sank ten miles out of Stockholm.

definitions.definition: available to everyone; known to everyone

examples.text: When does her new book come out?
**Word** always **gets out** *(= people find out about things)* no matter how careful you are.
**Out with it**! *(= say what you know)*

definitions.definition: used to show the reason why something is done

examples.text: I asked out of curiosity.
She did it out of spite.

definitions.definition: not in the library; borrowed by somebody else

examples.text: The book you wanted is out on loan.

definitions.definition: at or towards its lowest point on land

examples.text: I like walking on the wet sand when the tide is out.

definitions.definition: if the sun, moon or stars are or come out, they can be seen from the earth and are not hidden by clouds
fully open

examples.text: There should be some snowdrops out by now.

definitions.definition: if a team or team member is out, it is no longer their turn with the bat

examples.text: The West Indies were **all out for** 364 *(= after scoring 364 runs* in ).

definitions.definition: if a player is out, they can no longer take part in the game

examples.text: If you have no more cards, you are out. The winner is the one with the most cards.

definitions.definition: if the ball is out, it landed outside the line

examples.text: The umpire said the ball was out.
The ball landed out.

definitions.definition: not correct or exact; wrong

examples.text: I was slightly out in my calculations.
Your guess was a long way out *(= completely wrong)*.
The estimate was **out by** more than $100.

definitions.definition: not possible or not allowed

examples.text: Swimming is out until the weather gets warmer.

definitions.definition: not fashionable

examples.text: Black is out this year.

definitions.definition: not or no longer burning or lit

examples.text: Suddenly all the lights went out.
The fire had burnt itself out.

definitions.definition: at an end

examples.text: It was summer and school was out.
She was to regret her words **before the day was out**.

definitions.definition: unconscious

examples.text: He was out for more than an hour and came round in the hospital.
She was knocked **out cold**.

definitions.definition: on strike

examples.text: The dockers stayed out for several months.

definitions.definition: to the end; completely

examples.text: **Hear me out** before you say anything.
We left them to **fight it out** *(= settle a disagreement by fighting or arguing)*.

definitions.definition: to be trying to get or do something

examples.text: I'm not out for revenge.
She's **out for what she can get** *(= trying to get something for herself)*.
The company is out to capture the Canadian market.

definitions.definition: going regularly to a place

examples.text: He was in and out of jail for most of his life.

definitions.definition: able to go outside again after an illness
travelling around a place

examples.text: We've been out and about talking to people all over the country.

definitions.definition: going or leaving

examples.text: As soon as I get my money I'm out of here!

definitions.definition: sad because you are not included in something

examples.text: We've only just moved here so we feel a little out of it.

definitions.definition: not aware of what is happening, usually because of drinking too much alcohol, or taking drugs

examples.text: He looks completely out of it.

wordOrigin: Old English ūt (adverb), ūtian (verb), of Germanic origin; related to Dutch uit and German aus.
